dataModel.title: Vegetation Database Component Description: --all modules--
dataModel.versionDesc: 1.0.3 not yet complete, added intially namedPlaceCorrelation table.
dataModel.author: M. Lee
dataModel.description: This file describes the vegbank database structure.

entity.entitySummary: This table store the concepts (assertions) that are linked to community names through the commUsage table.

attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value to each unique record in the commConcept table.
Foreign key into the commName table providing the name used for the community when it was defined by usage in a publication (which could be this database).
The name the community is based on, denorm of commName_ID

Foreign key into the Reference table to identify a reference in which the community was identified by a name. This could be a regular publication, or a self reference created by completing the commDescription field in reference
The commDescription is a description of the community concept by the party that contributed the concept.

Code that uniquely references this record, allowing reference to this record for this version of this database. Better than a primary key, which is automatically generated by a database and not globally unique. VegBank Accession codes are only generated by VegBank, and therefore data integrity can be guaranteed, unlike with a primary key (number).
Number of observations associated with this entity.

entity.entitySummary: This table correlates multiple community concepts as they change through time in the perception of a party

attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value to each unique record in the communityCorrelation table.
This is the foreign key into the CommStatus table "pointing" to a concept no longer viewed as standard by the party.
This is the foreign key into the communityConcept table "pointing" to a concept recognized by the party as a "standard" concept.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: The two concepts are exactly the same.
The reference concept (referenced in table:Status) fully contains the correlated concept (referenced in table:Concept), but also includes additional entities.
The reference concept is fully included in the correlated concept, but the latter concept contains additional entities.
The two concepts are not exactly the same. This leaves the possibilities that the reference concept is greater than, less than, overlapping, similar, or disjunct relative to the correlated concept.
The two concepts contain at least one common entity, and each concept also contains at least one entity that the other does not contain. Neither concept is fully contained in the other.
The two concepts contain at least one common individual.
The two concepts in question contain no common entities.
Although some correlation is likely, the party responsible for the this correlation has not made a determination.

attribute.attDefinition: This is the descriptive attribute that is used to relate the congruence between two concepts.
This is the start date for recognition by a party of a correlation between two concepts.
This is the stop date for recognition by a party of a correlation between two concepts.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores tracks the lineage of vegetation community concepts.

attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value to each unique record in the commLineage table.
This is the foreign key into the commStatus table "pointing" to a parent concept.
This is the foreign key into the commStatus table "pointing" to a child concept.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores vegetation community names

attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value to each unique record in the commName table.
The community name.
Foreign key into reference to identify the source of the name.
Field stores the date that the name was entered into the database.

entity.entitySummary: This table store the status of a community concept as perceived by a party at a time.

attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value to each unique record in the commStatus table.
Foreign key to identify the concept to which a party assigns a status
Link to a reference where the status was reported
Status of the concept by the party (accepted, not accepted, undetermined)

The commParent is a recursive key to the concept of the parent level in the classification hierarchy. For example, if this concept were at the association level, the parentClass would be a concept that is the parent alliance type.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: A grouping of associations with a characteristic physiognomy and habitat and which share one or more diagnostic species typically found in the uppermost or dominant stratum of the vegetation. (This definition includes both floristic and physiognomic criteria, in keeping with the integrated physiognomic-floristic hierarchy of the NVC. It is similar to the FGDC 1997 definition: a physiognomically uniform group of Associations sharing one or more diagnostic (dominant, differential, indicator, or character) species, which, as a rule, are found in the uppermost stratum of the vegetation.)
A recurring plant community with a characteristic range in species composition, specific diagnostic species, and a defined range in habitat conditions and physiognomy or structure.

the first physiognomic level in the NVC hierarchy; based on the structure of the vegetation and determined by the relative percentage of cover and the height of the dominant, life forms (Grossman et al. 1998).

a level in the NVC based on physiognomic grouping of vegetation units with broadly defined environmental and additional physiognomic factors in common. (FGDC 1997). Grossman et al. (1998) clarified this definition as a level in the classification hierarchy below subgroup which represents vegetation types that share a definite physiognomy or structure within broadly defined environmental factors, relative landscape positions, or hydrologic regimes. Both of these definitions derive from Whittaker 1962: a "community type defined by dominance of a given growth form in the uppermost stratum of the community, or by a combination of dominant growth forms."

the level in the classification hierarchy below subclass based on leaf characters and identified and named in conjunction with broadly defined macroclimatic types to provide a structural-geographic orientation (Grossman et al. 1998).

attribute.attDefinition: The commLevel attribute specifies a level in the taxonomic hierarchy to which a class belongs. Field commLevel is an open list with the possible values defined by the classification system employed. If the party responsible for the record in the commStatus table is using the U.S. National Vegetation Classification, the acceptable levels are defined in the Vegetation Classification Standard of the Federal Geographic Data Committee as adopted June 1997. The standard is available at http://biology.usgs.gov/fgdc.veg/standards/vegstd.htm and the allowable entries for each of the physiognomic levels are listed in the appendix (see http://www.fgdc.gov/standards/documents/standards/vegetation/tables19-41.pdf). If the Braun-Blanquet classification system is employed, the acceptable values are defined in the International Code of Phytosociological Nomenclature (Weber, H.E., Moravec, J. Theurillat, J.-P. 2000. Journal of Vegetation Science. 11: 739-769).
This is the date for which the status assignment by the party started.
This is the date for which the status assignment by the party ended.
Comments by party providing rationale for status assignment
Foreign key that identifies the party that made the status assignment

entity.entitySummary: This table links a community name with a concept.

attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value to each unique record in the communityUsage table.
This field is the foreign key into the commName table.
This field is the foreign key into the commConcept table.
This is the date on which the party applied the name to the concept.
This is the date on which the party ceased to apply the name to the concept.
This field shows the status of the application of the name to the concept by the party (standard, not standard, undetermined).

attListItem.attListValueDesc: Ecological Society of American Vegetation Classification Panel. 2003. Guidelines ver. 2
Ecological Society of American Vegetation Classification Panel. 2003. Guidelines ver. 2
Ecological Society of American Vegetation Classification Panel. 2003. Guidelines ver. 2
Ecological Society of American Vegetation Classification Panel. 2003. Guidelines ver. 2
International Code of Phytosociological Nomenclature (2000. J. Veg. Sci. 11: 739-769)

attribute.attNotes: Like FGDC of Forest Cover Class.
attribute.attDefinition: This is the name of the classification system wherein the name is applied (e.g., Scientific, Spanish common).
Foreign key that identifies the party that used the class concept with the name.
Comm Status which applies to this commUsage.

entity.entitySummary: This table store the concepts that are linked to plant names through the plantUsage table.

attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value to each unique record in the commConcept table.

This is a foreign key to the reference in which the name was used, thereby defining a concept.
The plantDescription is a description of the plantConcept by the party contributing the plantConcept.

Code that uniquely references this record, allowing reference to this record for this version of this database. Better than a primary key, which is automatically generated by a database and not globally unique. VegBank Accession codes are only generated by VegBank, and therefore data integrity can be guaranteed, unlike with a primary key (number).

entity.entitySummary: This table correlates multiple plant concepts as they change through time.

attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value to each unique record in the plantCorrelation table.
This is the foreign key into the plantStatus table "pointing" to a concept no longer viewed as standard by the party.
This is the foreign key into the plantConcept table "pointing" to a concept recognized by the party as a "standard" concept.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: The two concepts are exactly the same.
The reference concept (referenced in table:Status) fully contains the correlated concept (referenced in table:Concept), but also includes additional entities.
The reference concept is fully included in the correlated concept, but the latter concept contains additional entities.
The two concepts, are not exactly the same. This leaves the possibilities that the reference concept is greater than, less than, overlapping, similar, or disjunct relative to the correlated concept.
The two concepts contain at least one common individual, and each concept also contains at least one individual that the other does not contain. Neither concept is fully contained in the other.
The two concepts contain at least one common individual.
The two concepts in question contain no common individuals.
Although some correlation is likely, the party responsible for the this correlation has not made a determination.

attribute.attDefinition: This is the descriptive attribute that is used to relate the congruence between two concepts. The concept that is represented in the party perspective, via the Status_ID field is [this field, i.e. <,>,=] the concept represented in Concept_ID field. As normally used, (no Longer Valid Concept) [convergence] (Valid Concept). For example, if a concept is split, the convergence would be 'greater than' (The old concept is 'greater than' the new concept).
This is the start date for recognition by a party of a correlation between two concepts.
This is the stop date for recognition by a party of a correlation between two concepts.

attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value to each unique record in the plantLineage table.
This is the foreign key into the plantStatus table "pointing" to a child concept.
This is the foreign key into the plantStatus table "pointing" to a parent concept.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores information about references cited within the database

attribute.attDefinition: Primary key for the reference table.
The 'shortName' field provides a concise or abbreviated name that describes the resource that is being documented.
Full Text of the reference citation.
Describes the type of reference this generic type is being used to represent. Examples: book, journal article, web page.

The formal title given to the work by its author or publisher. The 'title' field provides a description of the resource that is being documented that is long enough to differentiate it from other similar resources.
A second, higher order title where appropriate, which in the case of a reference to a chapter is the Book title, and in the case of a Conference Presentation is the Name of the Conference.

The 'pubDate' field represents the date that the resource was published. The format should be represented as: CCYY, which represents a 4 digit year, or as CCYY-MM-DD, which denotes the full year, month, and day. Note that month and day are optional components. Formats must conform to ISO 8601. For example: 1999-10-26
The date the resource being referenced was accessed. This is useful if the resource is could be changed after formal publication, such as web sites or databases.
The date the conference was held.
Foreign key into the journal table to identify the journal of this reference.
The volume field is used to describe the volume of the journal in which the article appears.
The issue field is used to describe the issue of the journal in which the article appears.
The page range field is used for the beginning and ending pages of the journal article that is being documented.
The total pages field is used to describe the total number of pages in the book that is being described.
The organization that physically put together the report and publishes it.
The location at which the work was published. This is usually the name of the city in which the publishing house produced the work.
The ISBN, or International Standard Book Number that has been assigned to this literature resource.
The edition field is to document the edition of the generic reference type that is being described.
Number of volumes in a collection
The chapter number of the chapter of a book that is being described.
The report number field is used to describe the unique identification number that has been issued by the report institution for the report being described.
The type of personal communication. Could be an email, letter, memo, transcript of conversation either hardcopy or online.
The degree field is used to describe the name or degree level for which the thesis was completed.
A URL (Uniform Resource Locator) from which this resource can be downloaded or additional information can be obtained.

A Digital Object Identifier - a digital identifier for any object of intellectual property. A DOI provides a means of persistently identifying a piece of intellectual property on a digital network and associating it with related current data. (www.doi.org)
This field provides any information that is not characterized by the other resource metadata fields. Example: Copyright 2001, Robert Warner

Code that uniquely references this record, allowing reference to this record for this version of this database. Better than a primary key, which is automatically generated by a database and not globally unique. VegBank Accession codes are only generated by VegBank, and therefore data integrity can be guaranteed, unlike with a primary key (number).

entity.entitySummary: This table stores information about identifiers that can be used to indicate a particular reference.

attribute.attDefinition: Primary key for the referenceAltIdent table.
Foreign key into the reference table to indicate which reference is referenced by this alternate identifier.

The data management system within which an identifier is in scope and therefore unique. This is typically a URL (Uniform Resource Locator) that indicates a data management system. All identifiers that share a system must be unique. In other words, if the same identifier is used in two locations with identical systems, then by definition the objects at which they point are in fact the same object. Example(s): http://metacat.somewhere.org/svc/mc/

An additional, secondary identifier for this entity. The primary identifier belongs in the reference table, but additional identifiers that are used to label this entity, possibly from different data management systems, can be listed here. Example: VCR3465

entity.entitySummary: This table links reference parties with references and shows how a contribution was made by the party.

attribute.attDefinition: Primary key for the referenceContributor table.
Foreign key into the reference table to indicate which reference is referenced by this alternate identifier.

attribute.attFKTranslationSQL: (SELECT CASE WHEN surname is null THEN 'org:' || organizationname ELSE surname || ', ' || givenname END FROM referenceparty WHERE referenceparty.referenceparty_id=referencecontributor.referenceparty_id)
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign key into the referenceParty table to indicate which person contributed.
Use this field to describe the role the party played with respect to the resource. Some potential roles include technician, reviewer, principal investigator, and many others.
Numerical order in which this contributor's name should be in the order of contributors, if applicable. Examples: 1 [for the first author], 2, [for the second author], etc.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores information about parties that contributed to a reference.

attribute.attDefinition: Primary key for the referenceParty table.
Type of Party this record refers to: usually person or institution. Type determines rules for which fields must be completed.

This field is intended to be used instead of a particular person or full organization name. If the associated person that holds the role changes frequently, then Position Name would be used for consistency. Note that this field, used in conjunction with 'organizationName' and 'individualName' make up a single logical originator. Because of this, an originator with only the individualName of 'Joe Smith' is NOT the same as an originator with the name of 'Joe Smith' and the organizationName of 'NSF'. Also, the positionName should not be used in conjunction with individualName unless only that individual at that position would be considered an originator for the data package. If a positionName is used in conjunction with an organizationName, then that implies that any person who currently occupies said positionName at organizationName is the originator of the data package. Example(s): Niwot Ridge Data Manager
The salutation field is used in addressing an individual with a particular title, such as Dr., Ms., Mrs., Mr., etc.

The given name field is used for the all names, except the surname, of the individual associated with the resource. Possible usages include: first name and middle name, first name and middle initials, first name, etc. Example(s): Jo, Jo R., Jo R.W., John Robert Peter
The surname field is used for the last name of the individual associated with the resource.
A suffix or suffix abbreviation that follows a name. Examples: Jr., Senior, III, etc.

The responsible party field contains the full name of the organization that is associated with the resource. This field is intended to describe which institution or overall organization is associated with the resource being described. Note that this field, used in conjunction with 'individualName' and 'positionName' make up a single logical originator. Because of this, an originator with only the individualName of 'Joe Smith' is NOT the same as an originator with the name of 'Joe Smith' and the organizationName of 'NSF'. Also, the positionName should not be used in conjunction with individualName unless only that individual at that position would be considered an originator for the data package. If a positionName is used in conjunction with an organizationName, then that implies that any person who currently occupies said positionName at organizationName is the originator of the data package. Example(s): National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis
Recursive Foreign key into the referenceParty table to indicate the current name of the party.

Code that uniquely references this record, allowing reference to this record for this version of this database. Better than a primary key, which is automatically generated by a database and not globally unique. VegBank Accession codes are only generated by VegBank, and therefore data integrity can be guaranteed, unlike with a primary key (number).

The name of the journal, magazine, newspaper, zine, etc... in which the article was published. Example(s): Ecology, New York Times, Harper's, Canadian Journal of Botany/Revue Canadienne de Botanique ,The Journal of the American Medical Association
The ISSN, or International Standard Serial Number that has been assigned to this literature resource. Example(s): ISSN 1234-5679
Standard abbreviation or shorter name of the journal. Example(s): Can. J. Bot./Rev. Can. Bot., JAMA

Code that uniquely references this record, allowing reference to this record for this version of this database. Better than a primary key, which is automatically generated by a database and not globally unique. VegBank Accession codes are only generated by VegBank, and therefore data integrity can be guaranteed, unlike with a primary key (number).

entity.entitySummary: This table stores information about who participated in a classification event
entity.entityDescription: This table serves as an intersection entity used to link a party with a specific plot classification event.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the classContributor table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique contribution to the classification of a plot observation.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the commClass table.
attribute.attDefinition: Observation classification event to which the contributor is associated.

attribute.attFKTranslationSQL: (SELECT CASE WHEN surname is null THEN 'org:' || organizationname ELSE surname || ', ' || givenname END FROM party WHERE party.party_id=classcontributor.party_id)
attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the party table.
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the party that contributed to the classification event.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the aux_Role table
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign key that identifies the role that the party had in the classification event (e.g., classifier, consultant, research advisor).
This value mimics the default embargo value for the plot that this record belongs to.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores general information about classification events where one or more community concepts were applied to a specific Observation by one or more parties.

attribute.attNotes: Primary Key for the commClass table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique observation classification event.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the observation table
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the observation table identifying which observation is being classified.
Start date for the application of a vegetation class to a plot observation by one or more parties.
Stop date for the application of a vegetation class to a plot observation by one or more parties.
Classification informed by simple inspection of data.
Classification informed by inspection of floristic composition tables.
Classification informed by use of multivariate numerical tools.
Classification informed by use of automated expert system.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the reference table
attribute.attDefinition: Link to a publication wherein the observation was classified.
Notes about the classification event by the parties participating in the event. This might include the purpose or rationale for the classification.

Code that uniquely references this record, allowing reference to this record for this version of this database. Better than a primary key, which is automatically generated by a database and not globally unique. VegBank Accession codes are only generated by VegBank, and therefore data integrity can be guaranteed, unlike with a primary key (number).
This value mimics the default embargo value for the plot that this record belongs to.

entity.entitySummary: This table tracks the assignment of specific community concepts to plot observations

attribute.attNotes: Primary Key for the communityInterpretation table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique assignment of a community concept to a plot observation.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the commClassification table.
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the commClassification table identifying the specific classification event.

attribute.attFKTranslationSQL: (SELECT commname.commname from commConcept, commname WHERE commname.commname_id=commconcept.commname_id and commconcept.commconcept_id=comminterpretation.commconcept_id)
attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the commConcept table.
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the communityConcept table identifying the specific community concept being applied.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: (Fits well) No doubt about the match. Perfect fit.
(Absolutely doesn't fit) This answer is absolutely unacceptable. Unambiguously incorrect.
(Fits reasonably well) Good match with the concept. Unambiguously correct.
(Possibly fits) Maybe not the best possible answer but it is acceptable; this answer does not pose a problem to the user. Correct.

(Doesn't fit but is close) Not a good answer. There is something about the plot that makes the answer understandable, but there is clearly a better answer. This answer would pose a problem for users. Incorrect.

attribute.attDefinition: Indicates the degree of fit with the community concept being assigned. Values derive from Gopal, S., and Woodcock, C. (1994), Theory and methods for accuracy assessment of thematic maps using fuzzy sets. Photogrammetric Engineering and Remote Sensing 60(2):181-188.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: The party making the community interpretation has a high confidence in the accuracy of this interpretation. A party can have high confidence that a plot has a fit of "absolutely wrong" for a particular community.
The party making the community interpretation has a low confidence in the accuracy of this interpretation.
The party making the community interpretation has a medium amount of confidence in the accuracy of this interpretation.

attribute.attDefinition: Indicates the degree of confidence of the interpreter(s) in the interpretation made. This can reflect the level of familiarity with the classification or the sufficiency of information about the plot (e.g., High, Moderate, Low).

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the reference table
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the reference from which information on the community concept was obtained during the classification event. (A case could be made for this being moved to reference.)
Notes pertaining to the classification analysis and decision.

This assignment is the type description for the community concept, as indicated in the publication referenced in commClass.classPublication_ID (NOT the commAuthority_ID of this commInterpretation table).
Typal plot for the Braun-Blanquet community name.
This value mimics the default embargo value for the plot that this record belongs to.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores the definitions of each coverclass unit associated with each coverclass method.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the coverIndex table
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique coverclass associated index value.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the coverMethod table.
attribute.attDefinition: Links to a specific cover scale.
The name or label used in the coverclass scale for this specific coverclass.
Upper limit, in percent, associated with the specific coverCode.

This is the lower limit, in percent, associated with a specific coverCode. Where a cover scale has a non-quantitative lower or upper value, as in the "+" of the Braun-Blanquet scale, it is necessary to provide an approximation with "0" being the lower limit of the bottom most class.

A middle value (usually mean or geometric mean) between the upperLimit and lowerLimt stored by the database for each taxon observation and used for all coverclass conversions and interpretations. This is assigned by the author of the cover class schema.
Description of the specific coverclass. This is particularly helpful in the case that there is no numeric value that can be applied.

entity.entitySummary: This table associates a cover scale recognized by the plot data collectors with a set of coverclasses specified in the coverIndex table. This table, together with the coverIndex table, defines a coverclass method.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the coverMethod table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique coverclass methodology.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the reference table.
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign Key into the reference table, linking the defining reference to a cover method.
Name of the coverclass method (e.g., Braun-Blanquet, Barkman, Domin, Daubenmire, Carolina Vegetation Survey, etc.).

attListItem.attListValueDesc: Cover estimated as the percentage of ground covered by a vertical outermost perimeter of the natural spread of foliage of plants. (SRM 1989)

Cover estimated as the percentage of ground covered by the vertical portion of plants. Small openings in the canopy and intraspecific overlap are excluded (SRM 1989). Foliar cover is the vertical projection of shoots; i.e., stems and leaves.

attribute.attDefinition: The way that cover is estimated on the observation.

Code that uniquely references this record, allowing reference to this record for this version of this database. Better than a primary key, which is automatically generated by a database and not globally unique. VegBank Accession codes are only generated by VegBank, and therefore data integrity can be guaranteed, unlike with a primary key (number).

entity.entitySummary: This table stores the values of user-defined variables.
entity.entityDescription: This table stores values associated with specific user-defined variables identified in the userDefined table.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the definedValue table
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique defined value.
Link to a specific user-defined variable defined in the userDefined table.

attribute.attNotes: Pseudokey for the table with which this value should be associated
attribute.attDefinition: The numeric value of the record number (primary key) that this user-defined value would have if it were in the table identified by USERDEFINED_ID.
The value of the user-defined variable.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores plot observation information pertaining to observer estimation of the disturbance history of the plot.
entity.entityDescription: disturbanceObs is a child of observation; a plot might experience many types of disturbance unique to different observation events.

attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique disturbance observation..

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key that points to the parent observation for this disturbance record
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the observation event with which this report of a disturbance event is associated.
The type of disturbance being reported

attListItem.attListValueDesc: No disturbance of this type was observed on the plot. This may be a useful observation where certain types of disturbance are expected, but no signs of such disturbance were found.

attribute.attDefinition: Intensity or degree of the disturbance.
Estimated time in years since the disturbance event.
Percent of the plot that experienced the event.
Text description of details of the disturbance and its impact on the vegetation.
This value mimics the default embargo value for the plot that this record belongs to.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores information about graphical files related to vegetation plot observations
entity.entityDescription: Graphical files can include, among other formats: gif, jpeg, and tif file formats. Because many graphical files, especially remote sensing digital photographs, may be too large to be stored within the database, a graphicLocation may be given as an alternative. Current Business rules cap graphic size at 5M per plot. Graphics of modest size should be included rather than referenced by external address.

attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique graphic idem.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the observation table.
attribute.attDefinition: Link from a graphic file to a specific plot observation.
Name of the graphic file.
Where the graphic is located, if not in the database
Description of the graphical file and associated metadata such as contributor, author, sensor, etc.

entity.entitySummary: This tables stores information about the various 'named places' that a plot may have been located within. attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique named place.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: area, country, or territory
county, canton, or parish
User named places
region or state or province
A non-standard or generic ecoregion that is not specifically mentioned in this list.

attribute.attDefinition: Name of the system of names. These can be treated as points as with place names, or as a coverage or set of polygons (e.g., geographic area names, HUC codes, Ecoregions, Quadrangles).

The name of a place in or at which a plot is located. The system "Geographic Name" is an open list defined within this table. The other systems are generally closed lists constrained by aux_tables. These include at least USGSQuad, Continent, Country, State, County, HUC, and Ecoregion.
This is the description of a named place.
Optional code for location identification

Although somewhat redundant with the owner information contained in observationContributor with roleCode of owner, this allows the program to provide ownership information automatically. The ownership field supercedes this field in priority.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the reference table

Code that uniquely references this record, allowing reference to this record for this version of this database. Better than a primary key, which is automatically generated by a database and not globally unique. VegBank Accession codes are only generated by VegBank, and therefore data integrity can be guaranteed, unlike with a primary key (number).
Number of observations associated with this entity.

entity.entitySummary: Stores information about how different named places related to one another.

attribute.attDefinition: Primary Key.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the namedPlace table
attribute.attDefinition: Link to a parent geographical region.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the namedPlace table
attribute.attDefinition: Link to a child geographical region.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: The two places are exactly the same.
The parent place fully contains the child place, and also includes additional space.
The parent place is fully included in the child place, but the child place contains additional space.
The two places are not exactly the same. This leaves the possibilities that the parent place is greater than, less than, overlapping, similar, or disjunct relative to the child place.
The two places contain at least some common area, and each place also contains at least some area that the other does not contain. Neither place is fully contained in the other.
The two places contain at least some common area.
The two places in question contain no common area.
Although some correlation is likely, the correlation has not been determined.

attribute.attDefinition: This is the descriptive attribute that is used to relate the congruence between two places, Parent [convergence value] child (generally greater than).

entity.entitySummary: This table is where notations associated with table records are stored

The type of note: Database Management, Observation Author, Database User and Internal. "Database Management" notes are those added by the management team and may be queried and viewed by the public. "Database Use" notes are those entered by the users of the database and are publicly viewable. "Internal" notes are for management to use internally and will not be broadcast.
The text of the note.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores plot observation results that might vary between official observation events.
entity.entityDescription: Observation is a child of plot in recognition of the fact that a plot may be re-sampled and that some of the environmental conditions may change between resampling events.

attribute.attDefinition: Subjective assessment of floristic quality by the party that submitted the plot (e.g., Highest, High, High but incomplete, Moderate, Moderate and incomplete, Low).

attribute.attDefinition: How mature is the stand. Could be young, mature but even-aged, old-growth, etc.
Description of the assumed successional status of the plot. This description is of necessity highly subjective.
Total basal area of woody stems (in m2/ha).
What is the hydrologic regime, which is a reflection of frequency and duration of flooding? List is taken from Cowardin et al. 1979, 1985.
How moist was the soil at the sampling event?

attListItem.attListValueDesc: Soils are free from any evidence of gleying throughout the profile. These soils are commonly very coarse textured (e.g., >35% volume of particles > 2 mm in size) or soils on very steep slopes. Sometimes described as "very rapidly drained."

The soil moisture content seldom exceeds field capacity in any horizon except immediately after water addition. Soils are free from any evidence of gleying throughout the profile. Rapidly drained soils are commonly coarse textured or soils on steep slopes. Sometimes described as "rapidly drained."

The soil moisture content does not normally exceed field capacity in any horizon (except possibly the C) for a significant part of the year. Soils are usually free from mottling in the upper 3 feet (1 m), but may be mottled below this depth. B horizons, if present, are reddish, brownish, or yellowish.

The soil moisture in excess of field capacity remains for a small but significant period of the year. Soils are commonly mottled (chroma < 2) in the lower B and C horizons or below a depth of 2 feet (0.6 m). The Ae horizon, if present, may be faintly mottled in fine-textured soils and in medium-textured soils that have a slowly permeable layer below the solum. In grassland soils the B and C horizons may be only faintly mottled and the A horizon may be relatively thick and dark.

The soil moisture in excess of field capacity remains in subsurface horizons for moderately long periods during the year. Soils are commonly mottled in the B and C horizons; the Ae horizon, if present, may be mottled. The matrix generally has a lower chroma than in the well-drained soil on similar parent material. Sometimes described as "imperfectly drained."

The soil moisture in excess of field capacity remains in all horizons for a large part of the year. The soils are usually very strongly gleyed (low chroma colors, such as gray, bluish, or gray-green). Except in high-chroma parent materials the B, if present, and upper C horizons usually have matrix colors of low chroma. Faint mottling may occur throughout.

Free water remains at or within 12 inches of the surface most of the year. The soils are usually very strongly gleyed. Subsurface horizons usually are of low chroma and yellowish to bluish hues. Mottling may be present but at the depth in the profile. Very poorly drained soils usually have a mucky or peaty surface horizon.

attribute.attDefinition: Identifies the natural drainage conditions of the soil and refers to the frequency and duration of wet periods. The soil drainage classes are defined in terms of (1) actual moisture content (in excess of field moisture capacity) and (2) the extent of the period during which excess water is present in the plant-root zone. Soil drainage class categories conform to the FGDC Soil Geographic Data Standards, September 1997. (http://www.fgdc.gov/standards/documents/standards/soils/soil997.PDF.) Definitions are derived from Grossman et al. (1998) and Sims et al. (1997).

entity.entitySummary: This table stores information about which parties contributed to specific plot observation events.

attribute.attDefinition: Surficial deposits represent the parent material that are the geologic or organic precursors to the soil. entity.entitySummary: This table stores information about a project established to collect vegetation plot data.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the project table.

Project name as defined by the principal investigator.
Short description of the project including the original purpose for conducting the project. This can be viewed as the project abstract plus supporting metadata.
Project start date.
Project stop date.

Code that uniquely references this record, allowing reference to this record for this version of this database. attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the project table

entity.entitySummary: This table stores the valid soilTaxon records that may be used to describe the soil of a plot.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the aux_Soil table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value for a unique soil type
SCS Code
Name of soil type
Hierarchical level; 1=Order, 2=Suborder, 3=GreatGroup, 4=SubGroup, 5=Family, 6=Series
Parent soil taxon in the soil taxon hierarchy for this particular framwork. For example, in USDA soils list, the parent of a soil SubGroup would be the GreatGroup.

System in which this soil taxon is part. This field may be used to separate multiple soil taxonomic systems. Each unique soil taxonomic system should have all its soilTaxon records with the same soilFramework value. Correlation of different framework taxa is not currently possible.

entity.entitySummary: This table is intended to store information about the abundance of tree stems of a specific size.

attribute.attNotes: Primary Key for the stemSize table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique stem tally.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the taxonImportance table
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign key into the taxonImportance table, thereby associating a taxon identification with the tree stem(s).

The diameter of the stem in centimeters. When diameter classes are used, the stemDiameter is the midpoint between the low end and high end for the diameter class; the offset between this and the endpoints is stored in the stemDiameterAccuracy attribute.
The accuracy of the stem diameter measurements in centimeters. This represents the distance between the diameter class midpoint and endpoint.

The measured height of the stem in meters. When height classes are used, the stemHeight is the midpoint between the low end and high end for the height class; the offset between this and the endpoint is stored in the stemHeightAccuracy field.
The accuracy of the measured height of a stem, being the offset between the midpoint of the class and the endpoint, in meters.

attribute.attNotes: The default value is 1. This field is not logically necessary, but allows for more compact entry and storage of tree stem tally data.
attribute.attDefinition: The number of stems of a single species that have these specific stem diameter and height data in common.
This is the area in m2 used to infer the presence of the stem(s) referenced in this record. Overrides similar area field in taxonObservation, taxonImportance, and/or observation.
This value mimics the default embargo value for the plot that this record belongs to.

entity.entitySummary: This table is intended to store location information about individual tree stems.

attribute.attNotes: Primary Key for the stemLocation table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique stem observation.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the stemSize table
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign key into the stemSize table, thereby assigning a location to a particular stem of a specific size
Name or code applied to a specific stem in the plot. This is generally a numeric label to associate a field data entry with a stem in the database.
The X-coordinate of the stem position in m. The user will enter the relative position of stems with respect to the plot origin (in meters) with the x-axis defined by the plot azimuth.
The Y-coordinate of the stem position, as above.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: stem is dead
stem is uprooted, but still alive
stem leans in a non-trivial manner

attribute.attDefinition: Health of the stem referenced in this stemLocation record. Usually used to describe "dead" stems.
This value mimics the default embargo value for the plot that this record belongs to.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores collective information about strata defined within a plot observation.
entity.entityDescription: This table is used to record non-species-specific information about a stratum. Examples include total cover of the stratum and maximum height of the stratum.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the stratum table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value for a unique existence of a stratum within a plot observation.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the observation table.
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the plot observation event with which this stratum observation is associated.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the stratumType table.
attribute.attDefinition: This attribute will link to the definition of the specific stratum observed.
Average height to the top of the stratum in meters.
Average height of the bottom of the stratum in meters.
Cover of the vegetation within the given stratum in percent.

entity.entitySummary: This table links a set of strata to a sampling protocol . This table, when combined a set of linked stratum occurrences, defines the strata used by a plot observer.

attribute.attNotes: Primary Key for the stratumMethod table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique stratum methodology.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the reference table
attribute.attDefinition: Link to a publication defining the stratum method.
Name of the stratum method (e.g., Braun-Blanquet, TNC-ABI, NC Vegetation Survey #1, NC Vegetation Survey #2, etc.)

This field describes the general methods used for strata. For example, this field should distinguish as to whether strata are defined as including all foliage on plants that predominantly occupy the stratum regardless of the height of that foliage, or only the foliage that actually occurs within a specified vertical slice of the community.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: Each individual is assigned to one and only one stratum in which it most significantly occurs. Generally, this is the tallest stratum that the individual occupies.
Individuals are included in each stratum they occupy, allowing one individual to be assigned to multiple strata, if it crosses the height boundary between strata.

attribute.attDefinition: The way that an individual's cover is assigned to the different stratum. Some methodologies allow an individul to span multiple strata and have stratumCover values in each stratum. Other methodologies require that all cover from an individual be assigned to the upper-most stratum. Further information about the specifics of stratum Methodologies that deviate from the standard practice of the stratumMethod referened in the field stratumMethod_ID should be described in methodNarrative.

Code that uniquely references this record, allowing reference to this record for this version of this database. Better than a primary key, which is automatically generated by a database and not globally unique. VegBank Accession codes are only generated by VegBank, and therefore data integrity can be guaranteed, unlike with a primary key (number).

entity.entitySummary: This table stores collective information about strata defined within a plot observation.
entity.entityDescription: This table is used to record non-species-specific information about a stratum. Examples include total cover of the stratum and maximum height of the stratum.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the stratum table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value for a unique existence of a stratum within a plot observation.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the stratumMethod table.
attribute.attDefinition: This attribute will link to the stratum to the stratum methodology used.
Short code used to identify the stratum
Name associated with this stratum by the stratumMethod

This field describes the specific stratum. For example, a value of "F" under stratumIndex might have a stratumName = "Floating" and a stratumDescription = "foliage floating on or near the surface of water"

entity.entitySummary: This table stores information about the importance (i.e. cover, basal area, biomass) of each taxon observed on a plot. Records may be limited to one stratum or apply to all strata.

attribute.attDefinition: Database generated number which uniquely identifies this record of the table.

attribute.attFKTranslationSQL: (SELECT authorplantname from taxonobservation as to2 WHERE to2.taxonobservation_id=taxonimportance.taxonobservation_id)
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign Key into the TaxonObservation table to link to the information about the taxon for which this importance value applies.

attribute.attFKTranslationSQL: (SELECT stratumtype.stratumname FROM stratumtype, stratum WHERE stratum.stratumtype_id=stratumtype.stratumtype_id AND stratum.stratum_id=taxonimportance.stratum_id)
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign Key into the stratum table, if this record is limited to the importance of a taxon in one stratum. If null, all values in this record speak of the importance of the entire taxon across all strata.
Cover, in percent, of the taxon (potentially limitied to one stratum if stratum_ID has a value).
Total basal area of the species in m2/ha (potentially limitied to one stratum if stratum_ID has a value).
The biomass of the species in g/m2 (potentially limitied to one stratum if stratum_ID has a value).

attribute.attNotes: The area used to infer the importance values of the taxon, if not the same as observation.taxonInferenceArea.
attribute.attDefinition: This is the area in m2 used to infer the importance values (i.e. cover, biomass, basal area) in this record.
The Base of the Stratum in meters.
The Tallest part of the Stratum in meters.
This value mimics the default embargo value for the plot that this record belongs to.

entity.entitySummary: This table allows all users, including the author and/or subsequent interpreters, to attach taxon names and authorities to a specific taxon observation

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the TaxonInterpretation table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique interpretation of a taxon.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the taxonObservation table.
attribute.attDefinition: Link to a particular taxon observation.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the StemLocation table.
attribute.attDefinition: StemLocation record of a particular stem that is to be interpreted by this taxonInterpretation record.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the plantConcept table.
attribute.attDefinition: Link to a taxon in the plantConcept table. The entry in the plantConcept table will in turn point to a reference and a name used in the reference, thereby defining the taxon concept. The name that should be applied to the plantConcept will be party specific and will be found in the plantUsage table. For other than legacy data, the first interpretation recorded for a taxon observation should be redundant with the information contained in taxonObservation.PLANTNAME_ID + PLANTREFERENCE_ID.
The date that the interpretation was made.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the taxonName table.
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign key into the plantName (in the plantTaxa database) table to identify the name applied by the interpreter to the plantConcept. This field is not needed except in cases where there is a publication associated with the interpretation.

attribute.attFKTranslationSQL: (SELECT CASE WHEN surname is null THEN 'org:' || organizationname ELSE surname || ', ' || givenname END FROM party WHERE party.party_id=taxoninterpretation.party_id)
attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the party table.
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign key that identifies the party that made the interpretation, which could be the observation author.
Foreign key that identifies the role of the party making the interpretation (e.g., plot author, publication author, database manager, automated, plot contributor).
Categories for the interpretation (e.g., author, computer generated, simplified for comparative analysis, correction, finer resolution).

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the reference table.
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign key into reference table, which identifies a publication in which the interpretation was formally made, or in which the plot was used in a formal analysis.

This interpretation corresponds to the original interpretation of the plot author, as best as can be determined. There is no requirement that the authority match the authority of the author; only that the concepts are synonymous.
This interpretation is the most accurate and precise interpretation currently available.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: (Fits well) No doubt about the match. Perfect fit.
(Absolutely doesn't fit) This answer is absolutely unacceptable. Unambiguously incorrect.
(Fits reasonably well) Good match with the concept. Unambiguously correct.
(Possibly fits) Maybe not the best possible answer but it is acceptable; this answer does not pose a problem to the user. Correct.

(Doesn't fit but is close) Not a good answer. There is something about the plot that makes the answer understandable, but there is clearly a better answer. This answer would pose a problem for users. Incorrect.

attribute.attDefinition: Indicates the degree of fit with the plant concept being assigned. Values derive from Gopal, S., and Woodcock, C. (1994), Theory and methods for accuracy assessment of thematic maps using fuzzy sets. Photogrammetric Engineering and Remote Sensing 60(2):181-188.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: The party making the taxon interpretation has a high confidence in the accuracy of this interpretation. A party can have high confidence that a plot has a fit of "absolutely wrong" for a particular community.
The party making the taxon interpretation has a low confidence in the accuracy of this interpretation.
The party making the taxon interpretation has a medium amount of confidence in the accuracy of this interpretation.

attribute.attDefinition: Indicates the degree of confidence of the interpreter(s) in the interpretation made. This can reflect the level of familiarity with the classification or the sufficiency of information about the plot (e.g., High, Moderate, Low).

attribute.attFKTranslationSQL: (SELECT CASE WHEN surname is null THEN 'org:' || organizationname ELSE surname || ', ' || givenname END FROM party AS pcoll WHERE pcoll.party_id=taxoninterpretation.collector_id)
attribute.attNotes: foreign key into the Party table
attribute.attDefinition: Party who collected the voucher which was used to make this taxonInterpretation.
The Collector's identification code for the voucher.
Date on which the voucher was collected.

attribute.attFKTranslationSQL: (SELECT CASE WHEN surname is null THEN 'org:' || organizationname ELSE surname || ', ' || givenname END FROM party AS pmus WHERE pmus.party_id=taxoninterpretation.museum_id)
attribute.attNotes: foreign key into the Party table
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the Party which is the museum which archives the voucher.
Museum Code which identifies the voucher.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: One of several plant concepts is interpreted to be the TaxonObservation in question. For example, this is either species A OR species B. Plants observed were one or the other, but not both, but which species cannot be determined.
Several plant concepts are grouped to describe this taxon. For example, taxonObservation applies to the union of both species A and species B. Plants observed were from both species.
It is not specified how the plant concepts are grouped. Not recommended value.

attribute.attDefinition: The type of group formed for this taxonInterpretation_ID.
These are notes that the interpreter has included with the interpretation (generally, the reason for the interpretation).
TRUE indicates that public notes pertaining to this plot exist in "vegPlot.note"

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the reference table.
attribute.attDefinition: The authority for the taxon that was used by the plot author. If the authority is unknown the author of the plot is the authority. For other than legacy data, this field plus plantName_ID will be sufficient to determine taxonInterpretation.plantConcept_ID.

attribute.attNotes: The area used to infer the presence of the taxon, if not the same as observation.taxonInferenceArea.
attribute.attDefinition: This is the area in m2 used to infer the presence of a given taxon. Generally this should be equal to observation.taxonInferenceArea, but at times this area may be larger or smaller for a specific taxon.

entity.entitySummary: User stored datasets

attribute.attDefinition: Database generated unique key for each record in this table.
Foreign key pointing to the user to whom this dataset belongs.
Date of start of dataset.
Date of end of dataset, if deemed no longer active.
Accession Code of the dataset, to be used to reference the observations contained here with a URL pointing to this dataset. Helps avoid URL's that are too long.
Name of Dataset, should be unique for each user.
Description of dataset.
Type of dataset.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: anyone can view this dataset - it is listed among public datasets
no one can view this dataset except the user who created it
no one may view this dataset except with a password, as specified in this table.

attribute.attDefinition: OK to share this dataset with others? Note that the dataset must be public or password-protected to be accessed via the accessionCode.
Password to access the dataset if the dataset is password protected.

entity.entitySummary: Items (entities) that belong to a user's dataset.

attribute.attDefinition: Database generated unique key for each record in this table.
Foreign key to the dataset in which the observation in this record is a member.

attribute.attNotes: accessionCode for observation that is part of dataset: used instead of observation_ID to allow observations from any database
attribute.attDefinition: Accession Code for the observation which is a member of the dataset referenced in userDataset_ID. Accession codes are used so that observations from any VegBank database can be included in the dataset.

attribute.attNotes: accessionCode for an incoming piece of data
attribute.attDefinition: Accession Code for an incoming piece of data.
Type of item/entity that this is.
Start date for the validity of this record.
Stop date for the validity of this record.
Notes about the observation as part of the dataset.

entity.entitySummary: User requests to be notified if certain criteria in VegBank change

attribute.attDefinition: Database generated unique key for each record in this table.
Foreign key pointing to the user to whom this notification request pertains.
Name of notification, included in emails to user.
Description of notification, which will be included in emails to user.
start of notifications.
stop date of notifications.
date of last check, assuming these requests will be processed through a cron-job.
SQL that returns whatever information the user would like to know. Preferably, these grab accession codes which would be easy to build hyperlinks to the info requested.

entity.entitySummary: Permission for user to see embargoed plot.

attribute.attDefinition: Database generated unique key for each record in this table.
Foreign key into the Embargo table that identifies which embargo this permission overrides.
Foreign key into the user table which identifies the user to whom this permission is granted.
Start date of permission
Stop date of permission

attListItem.attListValueDesc: Public
1 km radius
10 km radius
100 km radius
Location embargo
Public embargo on data
Full embargo on data

attribute.attDefinition: Status granted to the user for viewing.
Notes that the embargo owner may include with the permission.

entity.entitySummary: User stored queries.

attribute.attDefinition: Database generated unique key for each record in this table.
Foreign key to the user who created and owns this query.
Start date for query.
Stop date for query.
Accession Code used to see this query and its results.
Name of query, provided by user.
Description of query, provided by user.
SQL that identifies objects in question.

attribute.attNotes: plot query, plant query, party query, etc.
attribute.attDefinition: Type of query that this is - user specified.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: anyone can view this query- it is listed among public queries
no one can view this query except the user who created it
no one may view this query except with a password, as specified in this table.

attribute.attDefinition: type of sharing, if any allowed.
Password to access query, if query is password-protected.

entity.entitySummary: Generic table to store user Preferences.

attribute.attDefinition: Database generated unique key for each record in this table.
Foreign key pointing to the user whose preference this is.
Name of preference.
Value of the preference.

The priority rank of this preference if there are more than one preference with the same value. Useful if options are not always available. For example, the first rank priority could instruct VegBank to show plantConcept with common Name system. A second preference could specify that if the first pref is unavailable, use Scientitic Name.
start of notifications.
stop date of notifications.

entity.entitySummary: Information about what user owns what table records in vegbank

attribute.attDefinition: Database generated number to uniquely identify this row in this table.
Foreign key pointing to the user about which this ownership applies.
Name of the table that the ownsership is associated with.
The record number (row) containing the value with which the ownership is associated (which translates to the primary key value for the table wherein the record is stored).
Date the record in question was created in VegBank. This could be different from OwnerStart if ownership was transferred to another user.
Start date of the ownership of the record specified.
Stop date of the ownership of the record specified.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: full ownership of record
incomplete ownership of record, privileges are limited

attribute.attDefinition: The degree of control the owner has over the record in question.

entity.entitySummary: Keywords about different entities, so as to faciliate search for these items.

attribute.attDefinition: Table Name for entity to which these keywords apply.
List of space delimited keywords which apply to the entity in question.
PK of table to identify which entity in the table is mentioned here.

entity.entitySummary: A temp table to collect keywords to put back into keywords table, grouping by unique entities

attribute.attDefinition: Table Name for entity to which these keywords apply.
List of space delimited keywords which apply to the entity in question.
PK of table to identify which entity in the table is mentioned here.
